content: The Administration requested $39.510 billion for DHS in FY2013, a slight decrease from the previous year. The Senate Committee on Appropriations approved a net discretionary appropriation of $39.514 billion for DHS for FY2013. The Senate-reported bill for DHS in FY2013 provided $39,514 million, excluding funds for overseas contingency operations and disaster relief. The House passed H.R. 5855 with amendments, resulting in a net discretionary appropriation of $39,114 million for DHS. Funding for certain activities was 27% below the requested level. The President signed H.J.Res. 117 into law as P.L. 112-175 on September 28, 2012, a continuing resolution allowing federal government operations through March 27, 2013. It passed the House 329-91 on September 13, 2012, and the Senate 62-30 on September 22, 2012. On March 26, 2013, the President signed H.R. 933 into law as P.L. 113-6, the FY2013 Consolidated and Further Continuing Appropriations Act, including $39.646 billion for the Department of Homeland Security. The Department of Homeland Security Appropriations Act, 2013 allocated $39.646 billion in adjusted net discretionary budget authority for DHS. Two across-the-board cuts reduced the discretionary budget authority by $52.4 million. After the impact of sequestration, $38.348 billion was available for DHS to use. The Homeland Security Act of 2002 transferred functions, funding, and personnel to the Department of Homeland Security. Appropriations for DHS are organized into five titles, including offices like OSEM, USM, CBP, ICE, TSA, USCG, and Secret Service. Title III of the Homeland Security Act of 2002 includes appropriations for various agencies within the Department of Homeland Security, such as NPPD, OHA, and FEMA. Title IV covers USCIS, S&T, and FLETC. Title V contains general provisions for congressional direction. Additional titles may be added for special issues, like the FY2012 House mark-up adding a sixth title for a $1 billion emergency appropriation for the DRF. The Senate version typically does not include additional titles beyond those mentioned. The FY2013 appropriations bills had parallel structures with some differences in subcomponents and accounts. Congress determines budget authority through a two-stage process, with overall spending totals set in the annual concurrent resolution on the budget. These amounts are then allocated among appropriations committees, known as 302(a) allocations, for enactment in annual appropriations bills. The appropriations process involves subcommittees developing bills, with appropriations committees allocating 302(a) discretionary funds to subcommittees in the form of 302(b) allocations. These allocations must not exceed the 302(a) allocation to enforce budget discipline. Adjustments to 302(b) allocations can be made throughout the year. Congress mandated an automated entry and exit data system for aliens. The entry-exit system, mandated by Congress, tracks foreign visitors' entry and exit from the United States using biographic and biometric data stored in DHS databases. This information is shared with various government agencies to identify potential risks. The system has been operational at U.S. ports of entry since December 2006. Regulations issued in January 2009 require non-citizens entering the US to provide biometric data, but no data is collected from those exiting. The President's FY2013 budget did not include funding for a biometric exit system, focusing instead on an enhanced biographic exit program and a US-Canadian entry-exit system.
